Description: Glazed composition daisy button scaraboid, probably mould-made; decorated on the back with lines, possibly incised; underside bearing a hieroglyphic inscription arranged naming Amun-Ra.
Curator's comments: Numerous variants of the name of Amun-Ra were discovered on scarabs and scaraboids in Naukratis (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 89-93; Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 25 and 36), without including all the different cryptographic writings of Amun on Naukratis scarabs and scaraboids. This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII B, subtype B118-119, see especially B118 for this piece; on the various productions of the "Scarab Factory", see also Webb forthcoming). It was published twice by Gorton, as a daisy-button and as a disc-shaped scaraboid (Gorton 1996, 104, type XXVIII B118 and 145). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p.103, Type XXVIII B118 and B145) (published twice with two different numbers)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.091) (phase 3)
